policies.name: Configuration Management Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing system configuration management practices including information location tracking
policies.rationale: NIST 03.04.11 requires documenting CUI locations and changes; policy provides governance framework for this tracking

policies.name: Data Management Policy
policies.description: Policy defining how organizational data is classified, stored, and tracked throughout its lifecycle
policies.rationale: Control requires identifying where CUI is processed and stored; data management policy establishes requirements for data location tracking

procedures.name: CUI Identification and Location Documentation Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for identifying CUI, determining where it resides, documenting system components that process/store it, and maintaining location inventory
procedures.rationale: Control 03.04.11.a requires identifying and documenting CUI location; procedure provides systematic approach

procedures.name: System Change Documentation Procedure
procedures.description: Process for documenting changes to system or component locations where CUI is processed and stored, including change approval and location registry updates
procedures.rationale: Control 03.04.11.b requires documenting changes to CUI locations; procedure ensures changes are systematically recorded

procedures.name: Data Flow Mapping Procedure
procedures.description: Process for creating and maintaining data flow diagrams showing how CUI moves through systems and where it is processed/stored
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion emphasizes understanding 'specific system components where CUI is being processed and stored'; data flow mapping provides visual documentation

executionEvidence.name: CUI Location Inventory/Register
executionEvidence.description: Comprehensive registry showing: CUI data types, system components where processed/stored (servers, databases, applications, file shares), physical/logical locations, data owners, access controls applied, last verification date
executionEvidence.rationale: Control 03.04.11.a requires identification and documentation of CUI locations; inventory provides centralized record. Quarterly review aligns with typical configuration management cycles

executionEvidence.name: System Component Inventory with CUI Designation
executionEvidence.description: Asset inventory showing: component ID, component type, whether component processes/stores CUI (yes/no), CUI categories if applicable, location, ownership, related controls applied
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST requires documenting 'system components on which the information is processed and stored'; component inventory must flag CUI-handling systems

executionEvidence.name: CUI Location Change Logs
executionEvidence.description: Records of location changes showing: change date, system/component affected, old location, new location, reason for change, approver, updated documentation references
executionEvidence.rationale: Control 03.04.11.b specifically requires documenting changes to CUI locations; change log provides audit trail of modifications

executionEvidence.name: Data Flow Diagrams
executionEvidence.description: Visual diagrams showing: CUI data flows between systems, processing locations, storage repositories, network boundaries crossed, encryption points, access control points, last update date
executionEvidence.frequency: Reviewed and updated semi-annually or per major system changes
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion emphasizes understanding where CUI is processed; data flow diagrams provide comprehensive visualization of CUI movement and location

executionEvidence.name: Quarterly CUI Location Verification Reports
executionEvidence.description: Validation reports showing: systems reviewed, CUI locations verified, discrepancies found, corrections made, new CUI locations identified, reviewer signatures, completion date
executionEvidence.rationale: Periodic verification ensures CUI location documentation remains accurate and complete as systems change; quarterly frequency balances thoroughness with operational impact

operationalActivities: Identify all CUI data within the organization
Document system components that process or store CUI
Map data flows showing CUI movement through systems
Maintain centralized CUI location inventory
Update location documentation when systems change
Verify CUI location accuracy quarterly
Review and update data flow diagrams semi-annually
Apply appropriate access controls based on CUI location
Train personnel on CUI identification and location documentation requirements

controls.controlTitle: System and Component Configuration for High-Risk Areas

policies.name: Configuration Management Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing system configuration standards including special configurations for high-risk scenarios
policies.rationale: NIST 03.04.12 requires defined system configurations for high-risk travel; policy establishes governance framework

policies.name: Travel Security Policy
policies.description: Policy defining security requirements for organizational systems taken to high-risk locations, including pre-travel preparations and post-travel procedures
policies.rationale: Control specifically addresses travel to high-risk areas; dedicated travel security policy provides comprehensive guidance on requirements, definitions, and procedures

policies.name: Acceptable Use Policy
policies.description: Policy defining acceptable use of organizational systems including restrictions during high-risk travel
policies.rationale: NIST discussion mentions 'limited applications and more stringent configuration settings' for high-risk travel; acceptable use policy defines usage restrictions

procedures.name: High-Risk Travel Device Provisioning Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for: identifying high-risk locations, determining required hardened configurations, provisioning travel devices with sanitized drives and limited applications, pre-travel security briefing
procedures.rationale: Control 03.04.12.a requires issuing systems with specific configurations for high-risk travel; procedure defines provisioning process

procedures.name: Post-Travel Device Security Check Procedure
procedures.description: Process for examining returned devices including: physical inspection for tampering, malware scanning, log review, determination of purge/reimage requirements, approval for reconnection to network
procedures.rationale: Control 03.04.12.b requires applying security requirements upon return; NIST discussion specifically mentions examining for tampering and purging/reimaging

procedures.name: Device Sanitization and Reimaging Procedure
procedures.description: Technical process for securely wiping device storage, reimaging with approved baseline, verifying configuration compliance, documenting sanitization completion
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion states 'purging and reimaging the device storage' as action applied to devices upon return from travel

executionEvidence.name: High-Risk Location Designation List
executionEvidence.description: Approved list showing: countries/regions designated as high-risk, threat assessment summary, designation date, review/approval authority, last review date
executionEvidence.frequency: Reviewed and updated quarterly or based on threat intelligence
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion states organizations must determine 'whether the locations are of concern'; formal designation list provides basis for control application

executionEvidence.name: Travel Device Hardened Configuration Standards
executionEvidence.description: Technical specifications showing: baseline configuration for travel devices, applications permitted, disabled features/services, encryption requirements, remote wipe capability, logging requirements
executionEvidence.frequency: Reviewed annually or per threat changes
executionEvidence.rationale: Control 03.04.12.a requires 'organization-defined system configurations'; documented standards define these hardened configurations

executionEvidence.name: Pre-Travel Device Checkout Records
executionEvidence.description: Records for each travel event showing: traveler name, destination, travel dates, device issued (serial number), configuration verification checklist completed, security briefing provided, checkout date/time, authorizing official
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion requires 'ensuring that the components are configured as intended before travel is initiated'; checkout records document compliance

executionEvidence.name: Post-Travel Device Inspection Reports
executionEvidence.description: Inspection reports showing: device serial number, return date, physical inspection results (signs of tampering), malware scan results, log analysis findings, purge/reimage decision and rationale, inspection date, inspector signature
executionEvidence.frequency: Upon each device return from travel
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: N/A - must occur before network reconnection
executionEvidence.rationale: Control 03.04.12.b requires applying security requirements upon return; NIST discussion specifically mentions examining for physical tampering

executionEvidence.name: Device Sanitization/Reimaging Logs
executionEvidence.description: Technical logs showing: device identifier, sanitization method used (wipe/reimage), completion timestamp, verification of baseline restoration, technician performing work, approval for network reconnection
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion states 'purging and reimaging the device storage' as post-travel action; logs document execution of this requirement

executionEvidence.name: Travel Device Inventory and Status Tracking
executionEvidence.description: Inventory showing: travel devices available, devices currently deployed (with traveler/location), devices pending post-travel inspection, devices cleared for reuse, device status (checked out/in use/inspecting/cleared)
executionEvidence.rationale: Operational necessity to track travel device lifecycle from checkout through return and clearance; enables accountability and prevents unapproved device usage

physicalEvidence.name: Device Physical Inspection Checklists
physicalEvidence.description: Physical inspection forms documenting: device exterior examination, port covers inspected, case integrity verified, unusual components/modifications noted, tamper seals checked, photographs of any anomalies, inspector signature
physicalEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion specifically mentions 'examining the device for signs of physical tampering' upon return from travel; physical inspection checklists document this examination

operationalActivities: Maintain and update list of high-risk locations based on threat intelligence
Define and document hardened configurations for travel devices
Provision travel devices with sanitized drives and limited applications
Provide security briefing to travelers before departure
Issue hardened travel devices with checkout documentation
Track travel device deployment status
Perform physical inspection of devices upon return
Conduct malware scans and log analysis on returned devices
Purge and reimage devices per post-travel security requirements
Maintain inventory of travel devices and their deployment status
Review and update travel security procedures annually
Train IT staff on device provisioning and inspection procedures
